section.para: This menu gives you access to a number of tools, including QA validation, match reports, an aligner, scripting, etc.

listitem.para: This quality assurance tool carries out all automatic checks in one go and displays the results in a window.
Four types of issues can be detected:
Tag Issues (always selected): detects missing or displaced tags, including custom tags and flagged text. See the preferences for details.
Spelling Issues (optional): detects spelling mistakes. Only works if a spelling dictionary is installed. See the preferences for details.
Terminology Issues (optional): detects all the glossary items that are not properly translated. See the preferences for details.
LanguageTool Issues (optional): detects grammatical or typographical issues. See the preferences for details.
The results are presented as a table in which:
double-clicking a row activates the corresponding segment in the Editor pane,
clicking a column header changes the sort order for that column,
selecting a row, or moving the mouse over it, displays a context menu icon in the last column; clicking that icon presents actions available to correct or ignore the error.

note.para: To force issue checking each time you leave a segment, enable the preference.
To block translated files creation if tag issues are found, enable the preference.

listitem.para: As above, but only for the document currently displayed in the Editor pane.
Opens a new window and displays project statistics such as the overall project word count or segment totals, and totals for every file in the project.
The data is saved in the file located in the folder of the project.

note.para: Word count, segment total and other items can be influenced by the following factors:

listitem.para: File filter settings: some filters allow for extra parts to be considered for translation. See the file filter options for details.
Segmentation rules: different rules will generate a different number of segment. See the appendix for details.
Tags: OmegaT tags are never counted in the statistics but in some cases can split terms and create discrepancies in the way OmegaT counts them. See the preference in the dialog for details.
Custom tags and flagged text: as for OmegaT tags, they are not counted by default in the statistics, but you can have OmegaT count them as words. See the preference for details.
Displays the Match Statistics for the project: the number of repetitions, exact matches, fuzzy matches and no-matches for segments, words and characters.
The data is saved in the file located in the folder of the project.
Displays the Match Statistics for each file of the project: the number of repetitions, exact matches, fuzzy matches and no-matches for segments, words and characters.
The data is saved in the file located in the folder of the project.
Select the two files to align (the source file and its translation) and click OK to open the window.
The supported file formats depend on your project setting. See the appendix for details.
The source and target files can have different formats (for example, a .docx file can be aligned with a .pdf file).
Opens the window, which allows you to set the location where scripts are stored, as well as write and run scripts, and assign them a shortcut.
The list below this item displays 12 potential slots for scripts. Clicking on an assigned slot launches the script assigned to that slot.

note.para: To assign a number to a script:

listitem.para: Open the Scripting window
Select the script you want from the list on the left.
At the bottom of the window, right-click on an unassigned number and select Add Script.
If you have defined external searches in the preferences, their names are listed and accessible here.
